I also make this further request of you—to accom- 2 modate Avianius as regards both the place and the time at which he is to discharge his corn.‘¹ It was through me also that he secured both these privileges for a term of three years, when Pompey was in chief charge of that business. The main point is this (and you might greatly oblige me in that respect), that you should make it your object to convince Avianius, since he already assumes my affection for him, of your affec- tion for me. That will give me great pleasure.
